questions.question: What is an ionic bond?
options: A chemical bond formed by sharing a pair of electrons between atoms
A chemical bond formed by the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
A bond between two nonmetal atoms
A weak attraction between neutral molecules
questions.answer: A chemical bond formed by the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
questions.explanation: Ionic bonds form when one atom transfers electrons to another, producing positive and negative ions that attract each other.

distractor_rationale.0: Describes covalent bonding (electron sharing), not ionic.
distractor_rationale.2: Ionic bonds commonly form between metals and nonmetals, not between two nonmetals.
distractor_rationale.3: Describes van der Waals / intermolecular forces, not ionic bonds.

questions.question: Which ion is produced when sodium atoms lose one electron?
options: Na⁻
Na⁺
Na²⁺
NaO
questions.learning_objective: Recognise simple ion formation from electron loss/gain
questions.explanation: When sodium loses one electron it becomes a singly charged positive ion, Na⁺.

distractor_rationale.0: Na⁻ would be a negatively charged ion (gained an electron) — incorrect for Na losing an electron.
distractor_rationale.2: Na²⁺ would require loss of two electrons; sodium typically loses one.
distractor_rationale.3: NaO is not a single sodium ion; it's a compound fragment and incorrect here.

questions.question: When magnesium reacts with chlorine to form magnesium chloride (MgCl₂), what happens?
options: Each magnesium atom loses two electrons; each chlorine atom gains one electron
Magnesium shares electrons with chlorine to form covalent bonds
Each magnesium atom gains two electrons; each chlorine atom loses one
Magnesium and chlorine form a metallic bond
questions.answer: Each magnesium atom loses two electrons; each chlorine atom gains one electron
questions.learning_objective: Explain electron transfer and stoichiometry in ionic compounds
questions.explanation: Magnesium (Mg) loses two electrons to form Mg²⁺; each chlorine atom gains one electron to form Cl⁻. Two Cl⁻ ions balance one Mg²⁺, giving MgCl₂.

distractor_rationale.1: Electron sharing is covalent bonding, not what happens here.
distractor_rationale.2: This reverses the actual electron transfer; magnesium does not gain electrons in this reaction.
distractor_rationale.3: Metallic bonding occurs between metal atoms, not between magnesium and chlorine.

questions.question: Which property is typical of ionic compounds compared with covalent molecular compounds?
options: They have high melting and boiling points and conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water
They usually have low melting points and exist as gases at room temperature
They never conduct electricity in any state
They are always insoluble in water
questions.answer: They have high melting and boiling points and conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water
questions.learning_objective: Compare physical properties of ionic vs covalent compounds
questions.explanation: Ionic compounds form strong lattices (high melting/boiling points). Their ions are mobile when molten or in solution, so they conduct electricity.

distractor_rationale.1: Low melting points and gaseous state describe many covalent molecular compounds, not ionic lattices.
distractor_rationale.2: Ionic compounds can conduct electricity when molten or dissolved; this statement is false.
distractor_rationale.3: Many ionic compounds are soluble in water; this statement is too absolute and false.

questions.question: Which of these compounds would you expect to have the highest lattice energy (strongest ionic attraction)?
options: LiF
NaF
KCl
MgO
questions.learning_objective: Apply Coulomb's law qualitatively to predict lattice energy
questions.explanation: Lattice energy increases with larger ionic charges and smaller ionic radii. MgO has +2 and −2 ions, so the charge product is larger than the others (which are +1/−1), giving MgO the highest lattice energy.

distractor_rationale.0: LiF has small ions (which increases lattice energy) but only +1/−1 charges — smaller than +2/−2 in MgO.
distractor_rationale.1: NaF is similar to LiF but Na⁺ is larger than Li⁺, reducing lattice energy relative to LiF and far below MgO.
distractor_rationale.2: KCl has larger ions and only +1/−1 charges, so its lattice energy is lower.
